DOCNAME: CASE OF DENISOVA AND MOISEYEVA v. RUSSIA
CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of P1-1;Just satisfaction reserved
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;George Nicolaou;Giorgio Malinverni;Khanlar Hajiyev
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE . They are wife and daughter of Mr PERSON , who was also an applicant before ORG ( see PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , DATE ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of ORG of GPE ( the ORG ) opened criminal proceedings against PERSON . At TIME a search was conducted at the applicants ' flat . Foreign currency , the keys and registration papers for a ORG car , and the second applicant 's personal computer were seized . Simultaneously a search was carried out at Mr PERSON 's office . In total , the investigators seized MONEY .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigator seized from the first applicant the keys to garage no . CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON was formally charged with high treason , an offence under LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigator ordered a charge to be placed on the ORG car with a view to “ securing possible forfeiture of the defendant 's property in accordance with LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigator informed the director of the ORG bank of the freezing of Mr PERSON 's foreign currency and NORP rouble accounts .

CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE the investigator issued charging orders in respect of the garage and the computer . On DATE the computer was physically removed from the applicants ' flat and placed in the material evidence room of ORG .

CARDINAL . NORP On DATE the second applicant asked the investigator to return the computer , which was her personal property . On DATE the investigator replied that the computer had been seized with a view to securing possible forfeiture of Mr PERSON 's property and that certain files edited by PERSON had been discovered on the hard disc . The second applicant was informed that , if necessary , her text files would be copied and handed over to her .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigator ordered attachment of the seized MONEY as a material exhibit . On DATE ORG of the “ ORG ” issued a receipt for the money .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG convicted PERSON of high treason committed DATE , sentenced him to DATE and DATE imprisonment and issued a confiscation order in respect of his property . The parts of the judgments relevant to the determination of the property matters read as follows :

“ Mr PERSON 's pre - trial deposition that he had received remuneration for information transmitted to a representative of a foreign state has been confirmed by the search records , noting the discovery of GPE dollars both in his office and at his place of residence . The witness B. confirmed that the search had uncovered MONEY sorted into non - standard envelopes .

Both Mr PERSON and his wife PERSON who was interviewed as an additional witness at trial , had been present during the search but raised no objections . Accordingly , the court considers that the decision attaching the MONEY seized in PERSON office , the MONEY , and CARDINAL envelopes as material exhibits was justified ...

Having regard to the public dangerousness of the committed crime , the court orders confiscation of Mr PERSON 's property . The court decides on the destiny of the material exhibits in accordance with LAW ...

A confiscation order is issued in respect of the property that has been seized : [ the ORG car , foreign currency and NORP rouble bank accounts , garage no . CARDINAL , and the computer ] , as well as the cash funds of MONEY which have been criminally acquired . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant asked ORG to order the return of her spousal property and to remove the garage from the list because it was rented rather than owned . She did not receive a response to her request .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the conviction .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG sent an excerpt from the judgment of DATE to the ORG 's Finance and ORG for enforcement of the confiscation order in respect of the cash funds . The covering letter read as follows :

“ Confiscation order to be executed in respect of PERSON cash funds in the amount of [ unreadable ] GPE dollars as having been criminally acquired and stored at the ORG [ according to ] receipt no . CARDINAL of DATE . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued CARDINAL writs of execution for enforcement of the confiscation order in respect of Mr PERSON 's property at his place of residence , the ORG car , the garage , the bank accounts and the computer .
CARDINAL . On DATE the cash funds in the amount of MONEY were received by the ORG from the ORG 's Finance and ORG and credited to the ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE a bailiff discontinued enforcement in respect of Mr PERSON 's property located in his flat because no chargeable items had been found .

CARDINAL . By a decision of DATE , a bailiff ordered the removal and sale of the computer and declared enforcement completed . On DATE the computer was evaluated at MONEY ( RUB ) and subsequently sold for RUB CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . On DATE a bailiff discontinued enforcement in respect of Mr PERSON 's foreign currency and NORP rouble bank accounts . He determined that no accounts in his name were listed in the bank 's database .

CARDINAL . On DATE a bailiff determined that the garage was in fact a collapsible metal structure located on a rented plot , in respect of which the rent agreement had expired . Accordingly , he held that its removal or sale were impossible .

CARDINAL . Following the amendments of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , PERSON asked ORG to relieve him from the auxiliary penal sanction in the form of the confiscation order . On DATE ORG found that the enforcement of the confiscation order had been discontinued or terminated in respect of everything but the ORG car . Since the auxiliary penal sanction of confiscation had been removed from LAW , ORG decided to return the car to PERSON . On DATE ORG of GPE upheld that judgment on appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant sued the court bailiffs and ORG before ORG of GPE , seeking to have the charging orders lifted and to have her right to CARDINAL of the marital property , excluding the bank deposits , recognised . She submitted that she had been married to PERSON since DATE and that ORG provided for equality of spouses ' portions of the marital property . Relying on PERSON pay statements , she argued that from DATE to DATE he had earned MONEY and thus the amount of MONEY could not be considered to have been unlawfully acquired . She indicated that the garage had been rented in DATE , and that the computer had been the second applicant 's property .

CARDINAL . On DATE , CARDINAL and DATE the court heard the parties . As the first applicant withheld consent to the substitution of ORG for the ORG and to PERSON as co - defendant , Mr PERSON joined the proceedings as a third party .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG delivered a judgment . The entire reasoning read as follows :

“ Having assessed the collected evidence , the court dismisses [ the first applicant 's ] claim because the judgment of ORG established that the contested property had been criminally acquired , which makes it impossible to recognise the plaintiff 's right to CARDINAL of the seized property , and also [ because ] the ORG is not a proper defendant in this case . Neither [ the first applicant ] nor Mr PERSON have been deprived of an opportunity to appeal against the conviction in the part concerning the contested property . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment on appeal , noting that the claimed property had been found to have been criminally acquired by ORG judgment of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants sued ORG of GPE , seeking the lifting of the charging orders and recognition of the first applicant 's DATE of the spousal property and the second applicant 's ownership of the computer .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of GPE dismissed their claim , finding as follows :

“ It follows from the judgment of DATE that the cash funds in the amount of MONEY had been criminally acquired ... On DATE they were deposited with the ORG bank with a view to confiscation and credit to the State ... Accordingly , the court can not agree with PERSON claim to CARDINAL of the spousal part of the said cash funds . No other judicial documents relating to the origin of the contested cash funds have been produced before the court , whereas , pursuant to LAW , the facts established by a final judicial decision in an earlier case bind the court .

As to PERSON claims for recognition of her ownership of the computer and peripherals , it can not likewise be satisfied because they have not been corroborated during the examination of the merits of the case . At present the said property has been confiscated and sold , which is confirmed by the bailiffs ' information about the enforcement of the confiscation order in that respect . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld , in a summary fashion , ORG judgment .

CARDINAL . Property acquired by spouses in marriage is presumed to be jointly owned ( LAW , LAW ) . A child owns property which he or she has received as a gift ( LAW ) . Giving does not require a written agreement , handover of the gift being sufficient ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . The Criminal Code provides that “ penalty shall be imposed on a person found guilty of commission of a crime ” ( DATE ) . Confiscation of property is a form of penal sanction which is auxiliary to the main sanction and defined as “ compulsory withdrawal , in whole or in part , without compensation , of the property owned by the convicted person ” ( LAW . On DATE , Article CARDINAL was removed from LAW .

CARDINAL . As worded at the time of Mr PERSON 's conviction , LAW provided that high treason carried a punishment of up to DATE imprisonment that may or may not be accompanied by a confiscation order in respect of the convict 's property . On DATE the reference to the possibility of issuing a confiscation order was deleted .
CARDINAL . The RSFSR Code of Criminal Procedure , as worded at the time of Mr PERSON 's conviction , provided as follows :
“ The judgment ... must decide on the destiny of the exhibits , and :
( CARDINAL ) instruments of crime which belong to the accused shall be confiscated and passed on to a competent agency or destroyed ;

( CARDINAL ) NORP criminally acquired money and other assets shall be confiscated to the profit of the ORG ; other items shall be returned to their lawful owners , or , if the owners can not be established , shall become the ORG 's property . In case of a dispute over the ownership of such items , the dispute shall be resolved in civil proceedings ... ”

“ With a view to securing a civil claim or a possible confiscation order , the investigator must charge the property of the suspect , defendant ... or of the other persons who keep criminally acquired property ... If necessary , the charged property may be impounded ... ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure provides :
“ A dispute over the ownership of the charged property initiated by persons who were not parties to the case shall be examined as a civil claim .

A claim for having the charging order lifted shall be made against the debtor and creditor . If the property has been charged or seized in connection with a confiscation order , the person whose property is to be confiscated , and the competent ORG authority shall be co - defendants ... ”
CARDINAL . Resolution no . CARDINAL of ORG of the GPE “ On the case - law concerning confiscation of property ” ( of DATE , as amended on CARDINAL DATE ) provided :

“ CARDINAL . ... The court should bear in mind that in case of confiscation of the convict 's property in its entirety , the confiscation order should only apply to his or her personal property and to his or her part of the jointly owned property , it may not extend to the part of other persons who own that property jointly with the convict . Rights and lawful interests of the convict 's family members living with him , must be respected ...

CARDINAL . The courts should bear in mind that even if the criminal judgment contained a list of specific property items liable to confiscation , third parties still may claim their title to that property in civil proceedings ... The courts must consider such claims and the criminal judgment does not bind the civil court in its determination of the dispute over the contested property .

However , if the criminal judgment established that the listed property items had been criminally acquired or paid for with criminally acquired assets , but registered in other persons ' names with a view to concealing them from confiscation ... then the claim for lifting of the charging order shall be dismissed . ”
CARDINAL . Resolution no . CARDINAL of ORG of the GPE “ On legal requirements for examination of claims for lifting of charging orders ” ( of DATE , as amended on CARDINAL DATE ) provided :

“ CARDINAL . When considering a spouse 's claim for lifting the charging order in respect of his or her part in the joint marital property , the court must bear in mind that ... the property acquired in marriage is jointly owned by the spouses and in case of division their parts are presumed equal ...

The court must determine the actual size of the spouse 's portion of the marital property and the specific items allocated to him or her , having regard to the entirety of the jointly acquired property , including the property that is not – by operation of law or otherwise – liable to confiscation . Each spouse 's portion shall include both the property liable to confiscation and that not liable to confiscation ... ”
